content.rendered:
What is an Aerospace Engineer?

Aerospace Engineers are engineers who specialize in the creation and development of aircraft and spacecraft. Some standard responsibilities include overseeing the design and maintenance of spacecraft, weapons, and their impact and build.

Where does an Aerospace Engineer work?

  • Government agencies
  • Engineering firms
  • Offices
  • Laboratories
  • Production factories

How much do Aerospace Engineers make?

Based on real new grad salaries reported through Handshake, the median annual salary for an aerospace engineer is $66,297.

What majors are typically interested in becoming Aerospace Engineers?

One’s major doesn’t necessarily determine their career, but these are some common majors of those who end up pursuing Aerospace Engineering jobs.

  • Aerospace engineering majors
  • General engineering majors
Search Aerospace Engineering job opportunities on Handshake.

Aerospace Engineer skills and competencies:

On top of a relevant degree and formal training, here are some professional skills that can help aspiring Aerospace Engineers succeed in their work:

  • Strong analytical skills
  • Knowledge of MATLAB programming language
  • A Professional Engineering (PE) license might be needed down the line

What are some common questions about Aerospace Engineers?

Q: How to become an Aerospace Engineer?

A: If you’re interested in becoming an Aerospace Engineer, a great place to start is by deciding on your major. Choosing aerospace engineering or a related engineering field, like civil or electrical engineering, is key! Your major will give you training and knowledge that can set you up for success down the line. Then, while you work on your courses, start applying to internships and jobs at places that will give you credible experience for when you go on to apply to full-time jobs down the line.
